author: peterlabberton
content: Long time LWMR discord-ers may remember that I’m building a studio (/small lil house), and at long last, we’ve broken ground! Or maybe more accurately, broken a bunch of dry wall and shitty drop ceiling panels. Fucking psyched. Studio room will be in the far corner from this perspective, with tielines to the (small) living room, and a full on @Gerhard Westphalen build.

author: P.K. Stephan
content:
Hey guys! I am new to the community and happy to have finally taken the jump into the discord after being an avid listener since the beginning.

Just finished building my studio about half a year ago. I run a hybrid setup where everything is always connected and ready to go. All recording paths are accessed via an XLR patch-bay. Mixbus/Mastering gear is controlled by a Dangerous Liaison. Conversion is done via MADI and AES/EBU. Headphone CUE’s are analog and via AVB. I like having everything connected and mic’ed up because I notice that I only use the stuff that I can access quickly while producing/mixing. I went through a lot of trial and error building and working in this studio (been in this location for 1.5 years) so if anyone needs any input I would be happy to help!

author: denimes
content: Here’s some construction pics and measurements of my home studio I recently finished. Still need to do some final EQ correction to get rid of the bump at ~200Hz and flatten the midrange area. Overall I couldn’t be more thrilled with how it turned out. I designed the room with multilayer absorption all around. 1ft thick side walls, 2.5ft thick rear, and 6in ceiling (wish I had more ceiling height!) Monitors are our custom 3 way mains with hypex amps.

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I have a small room with a closet on the back wall and had been a little stumped trying to figure out how to treat it. @Rob Domos suggested that I use wheels and I ended up designing and building these. It's been a huge improvement sonically and still gives me access to the closet and a lot of flexibility (I can pull them into the room for a better air gap if I'm mixing or push them against the wall if I need more space). If anyone is interested in plans/materials I'd be happy to share.

author: Chase H
content:
This is my old Gerhard Build that a flood destroyed back in August. Got a lot of work done in there, loved how it sounded (the detail was overwhelming for months) and clients loved being in there. 

Not pictured is way more clouds, I’m not big on taking photos.

If anyone’s considering hiring Gerhard to design their room I can’t suggest him enough!

Som pictures are post Flood to show the membranes at the back 

Room was 
 Length 26.10 ft
Width 23.3 ft
Height varied but was around 7.6 ft tall

Back wall was were membranes of varying MLV density and then 1ft of pink fluffy in front of them.

I miss the old studio and am working on building the next one in a rental that’s across the country from where this studio was at. Right after the flood got a job offer I couldn’t refuse so me and my wife are about to start up the next studio build here 🙂

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay here we go…

@ALXCPH found a couple on my camera roll. Excuse quality, one is when I showed my parents the studio for first time. Couple (long) notes…I’m sure @Nomograph Mastering can expand if he chooses:

Unf*ck designed the room. Ruairi you are incredible at this and I’m very grateful. The subtleties in the trade offs when designing a room are something I urge everyone to consider deeply as I learned when working with them!

1. Studio is built in my basement…13 feet long x 30 wide x 8 tall (including treatment). Back wall divides it length wise and makes the studio part 12x15 approx.

2. All treatment is built in…entire ceiling is stuffed with 9 inch pink fluffy, couple inch rockwool in the walls, tuned mass loaded vinyl behind the “housings” to L and R of listening position. Back wall is 6 inches of safe n sound in a frame built of 2x8s (by contractor) with a 24” door. It’s standing by friction just slid tight to ceiling. Quite precise measuring required to do that and make it sturdy so a door can open well

3. Since I get asked a lot…the wall finishes are acoustic felt board. Went that direction because install was way better than a fabric wall (they are firm and can be cut with an exacto knife). Also they are absorptive with no reflections…caveats apply if that’s good for a given space though (rather than the acoustically transparent fabric).

5. @BatMeckley can confirm hard front wall was farrrr superior for me. I had a soft one (felt) against Ruairi advice since I preferred the aesthetic lol, but room was too dead. Uncomfortable. When I switched I could hear much more depth and energy but everything still as crisp and clear. Highly recommend! 

Hope this helps some people on here. FYI we started my room from concrete block, bare bones so could frame things to hold treatment needed.

Will circle back with some better pics when I’m home. This community has helped me greatly.

Cheers friends!

author: BatMeckley
content:
Having a proper vocal booth for Vox and guitar cabs was life changing for me. Being able to make decisions on the way in by hearing what’s actually being recorded and not the sound in the room (without having to use headphones) is the single biggest luxury of my spot. 

I’m sure a guy like EV or Cian had enough miles at barefoot to go “whelp, this is not what I’m hearing right NOW, but when the guitarist stops playing I know it’ll sound like THIS” but that kind of guessing game always bummed me out.

author: LAPhill
content:
@Zack Hames there are tiers to this. It'll be harder to suss out the quality of designers and contractors where you are, but get into studios there that are well-built and find out who did them. Decide what's most important to you (isolation? room response? vibe?) and allocate your resources from there. Do you really need that hardwood flooring, or would a laminate suffice? I cut corners on a few aspects of my studio, most of which turned out to be fine, but I'm now paying the price for something that likely could've been avoided had I spent more up front. 

I have colleagues that went with fancy architects/big name studio designers and spent twice as much as I did and had worse results. So price does not always equate to the final product.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: I use 2 PTZ Optics studio cams mounted up in the corner of each room, since my live room is downstairs from the control room. I sent active HDMI through the floor along with all the other cables so when we do sessions with someone downstairs, I switch my big monitor to show direct feed from the live room cam. And vice versa for the control room. You can configure them over IP but there's no latency issues since I'm viewing in real time with HDMI. And I can use camera audio coming out of TV speakers if i don't feel like setting up a talkback mic downstairs.

author: cian riordan
content: I think the attack wall solves the problem for people that can't build their room from scratch. As someone that just built a studio, building fake walls with insulation & membranes tucked behind aint cheap. And it's permanent. Having tube traps (or the ASC pressure traps, or whatever they are) are not a panacea -- but rather a scalable, portable method of getting an untreated room in the ballpark. I've found with tube traps that more is not necessarily better and you just don't know till you get in there and shoot it. My friend Andrew Maury raves about his. He's gets amazing results and he loves moving around his setup every few months just because he likes tweaking... and the attack wall allows him to do this. So -- if you're building a studio from the ground up, there are absolutely better options. But if you're hopping around from space to space and don't feel like spending $10-15k on framing, fabric, rockwool, & building limp mass membranes... these are a terrific option.

I have ideas, b/c this sort of stuff has been bugging me big time, but I'm holding off until I can start the real studio build.

The one thing I do have, and like, is the Hue lightbulbs folks were talking about recently. I don't fuck with the colors, but it's nice having dimmable lights all over, even on lamps and whatnot.

One thing I have not figured out is the computer monitor. It has to be too far away for good ergonomics (we all know this), but a cannot stand the screen really low thing—I crane my neck over instinctively and get *wild* headaches/neck pain. But where I have it now, I also crane my neck closer since it feels too far away. I've always hated big TVs for computer monitors in studios, too, but I'm debating going that route in the next spot and having big ass type like a true grandpa. Anyway, didn't mean to hijack!

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Yes, for sure! As a renter, work-from-home option, they are a dream. I think you could get better ergonomics and potentially better sound from other studio design options, but the flexibility is great. They are definitely not a magic bullet to get a “flat room” either and placement / quantity can affect things greatly. 

Andrew Maury was the one who inspired my initial purchase! He does fantastic work on them and was definitely a great resource as I was looking into them. He shared this video with Greg from Kush audio which was very convincing at the time  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=P7pOA4eeuS0&t=72m13s

I also have friends who have had good success building diy tube traps — which can be pretty affordable.

author: jantrit
content: It took me about a week to make 28 3ft traps for an attack wall. I did add some diffusion to them with mass loaded vinyl strips on half the surface  so it was a little more involved than the standard tubes. Well worth it though! Like @cian riordan said it’s gonna be itchy, long sleeves, jeans and a mask and gloves will be your friends. Also a cold shower when you’re done. It’ll close up your pores so the fibers can’t work as deep. The longest part of the process was using a jigsaw to cut the wooden caps for each end, this is absolutely needed for the traps to work properly and I’d recommend using a good quality construction adhesive like the gorilla stuff. Tried a bunch of diff ones and that was the only one that could get the job done.

author: cian riordan
content:
So here’s the roundup on my dumb drum thing. This is a scrappy little experiment on my part to see if I can get a convincing drum sound in my little drum room. Before starting this, I had the idea in my mind that if a room is good for mixing, it must be good for recording! *Insert Game Show Buzzer* I ran into many of the things I didn’t like about the Barefoot Studio B Live room — and those things were exaggerated by a factor of 10. First of all, my room is very dead by design. It treats me great in mixing, but made for a real challenge when trying to get *some* sort of drum personality. I was also working with a pretty shitty old premier kit that hadn’t seen the light of day in half a decade. Shitty cymbals, very quickly tuned heads — I wasn’t setting myself up for success… but whatever.

The setup was a little ridiculous (minus a few utilitarian pieces):
Kick: Beta 52 -> Scully 280
Snare: SM57 -> Scully 280
OH Mono: Coles 4038 -> Ampex 351 -> 1176 (not compressing, just to trim gain before ‘tools)
OH L/R: U67s -> UTA pre (thanks Matt!)
Kick Room: U47 -> UTA Pre (again…)

This is where I ended up, without mixing, and with some quick playing and utility EQ/balancing. No compression except a limiter to bring up the level. While the actual drums themselves don’t sound amazing, I really struggled with getting any sort of energy out of the drums… it all just got sucked out. 

Here are the results if you care (don’t judge my shitty playing)

I think if it do this again I would:
1) Have a better sounding kit. Turns out, shit in.. shit out. I knew this. We all know this. But here I am.
2) Maybe put some sheets of plywood around to create some surface in the room. Just give it some life.
3) Not use the Scully. It’s so hard to get them to not sound distorty… I just don’t have enough pres on hand to have clean path for everything. Mix studio living.

So it goes…

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I have a Hilo goes AES to speakers and as my send/capture for the Massive Passive...you can't see it here but there is a rack under the screen where it sits. I have a side car off the side (the walls look pretty tight but they are actually the unf*ck mass loaded vinyl L things, so the room opens up more behind them). The sidecar is back from those...its got a apogee symphony taking the ins for my synths (also not really pictured -- just hangarounds from my production days for the fun of it sometimes), Hazelrigg VLC in there too.

There is sorta a whole room behind the listening position...its 30 feet long with a floating wall for absorption about 15 feet in so the studio is like 13x15 but acoustically its larger if that makes sense.

I do use streamdeck...but mainly to switch quickly between the hot ref in Wavelab and my master. I've gotten deep into Applescript which essentially handles all of the other Wavelab processes...it's almost finished but my streamdeck will essentially just launch those applications to do what I need. So I'd say it's very useful, but the coding I've been able to do will render it sorta meaningless for me (though convienent, I use it for other things like navigating websites when doing client outreach, etc which is very handy and makes my workflow like an order of magnitude quicker).

Chair is hag capisco. I love it. Had a serious back injury when I was younger so I'm pretty dialed into having things be ergonomic and I find it's great. Actually kinda rather uncomfortable...in a good way. You can't really slouch. Took some getting used to but it's interesting

author: jmlongmusic
content:
Hey everyone! I’m new to the community - really enjoying it so far. This will be a long post asking for some studio build advice — I hope that’s ok. Please just let me know if there’s a better thread for this sort of thing. 

I’d be extremely grateful for any feedback! Here’s some info: 

- I am currently moving my home studio to this basement space that is about 400 SQ feet. Concrete floor and walls except for the front wall shown in this picture - that is drywall as it separates the rest of the basement. 

- The ceiling joists are exposed and are about 7.5” deep. 

- My primary function for this room will be mixing, but I will also be doing smaller overdubs like piano and vocals. 

Currently, after painting the walls and floor, my plan is as follows: 
- Stuff the ceiling joists with insulation — probably Safe N Sound… thoughts on that choice? 

- Cover the joists with fabric from Gilford of Maine. 

- Figure out how to drill into concrete 😂 Then put panels everywhere. Most of my panels are about 4” thick and are comprised of the safe n sound insulation. 
- Put some big rugs down but also leave a bit of the concrete exposed if possible cuz I like the look. Haha 

- My monitoring set up is NS10M’s (don’t laugh) with an Avantone CLA-100 amp and a PreSonus T10 sub. I’ve got an Apollo 8 Duo and Apollo Twin X Quad. 

That concludes my plan so far. Am I on the right track? 😳 

I really appreciate any feedback you’re willing to give. 🙏

author: ehutton21
content: Thank you 🙏 Only question I have is how much I should be watching heat and ventilation re: the unit. I realized my UA runs pretty hot and I’m sure support to service the preamp would be possible should I need it, but was curious if any other owners have had to pay mind to rack position/temperature during longer sessions.

author: Rollmottle
content: On first listen, the center image definitely jumped out as more defined. They were about a quarter inch out from each other before. They are now within sixteenths from the walls and within .5° level. Precision not easy with Sound Anchors and old construction!

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
This is my humble home setup in the corner of my bedroom. There’s nothing glamorous here. While I’m still building out the room downstairs and things have been at a hault due to some financial difficulties I won’t get into. I’m doing most of my work right here these days if I can’t get studio time at my buddys space. I’m incredibly proud of the mixes and masters I’ve been able to do in this little corner. I set up some gobos and tube traps I have in the closet when I’m getting deep into the mix and it’s all been working out as best as it can for the situation at hand.
NS10’s have the cap mod. 

When I need to track my guitar amps I completely isolate them with long cables and treatment directly in my closet or I will close off the bathroom and treat them in there as well as capture the natural reflection in our bathroom. My wife and kids are so incredibly sensitive and generous to me during this time to even let me still be able to work and make this happen while the studio build is on hold and we’re having to make things work.

I have the ability to do double doors with an air gap. Does anyone have recommendations that aren't incredibly expensive for doors or types of doors i should use for this? I am planning exterior door so it's all sealed with weatherstripping and the Threshold, etc. 

Are basic exterior Fiberglass doors, if doubled with an airlock / gap, enough to be decent? I'd love to not spend thousands and thousands on doors.

author: Eric Martin
content: I think you’re saying that while recording you’re hearing the distance bleed in the control room thinking your drum sounds were more roomy, and live sounding that they really were and a YOU didn’t listen back without the drummer playing?

author: cian riordan
content: Barefoot didn't have the best isolation being such an old studio. We had a decent sized iso booth next to the A control room that was this really cool, tubby sounding room. But it was only separated by a cheap, chincy glass door -- so whenever you'd do drums in there it was always a bit of a guessing game how it really sounded. But it was worth it for the character of the room. I remember when I first started building studios I was so obsessed with trying to get the best isolation... now I'd almost prefer a big open studio with clear sightlines and just use baffles or gobos to do spot isolation on mics.

author: hyanrarvey
content: Oh I am talking about bleed from the live room into the controll room not like isolating instruments

author: Zack Hames
content:
Yeah, isolation between things is pretty easy to manage even with just gobos. The booths at the studio are great.

Yeah, I'm trying to be able to have an amp in another room and play out of my monitors in the control room and have it be reasonably isolated.

author: LAPhill

About a year ago, I swapped a lot of gear between my writing room and machine room, which would have been an expensive nightmare if I couldn't just pull all sorts of different cables for v2.

author: cian riordan

author: masteredbyjack
content: @Eric Martin is the control room going to have drywall as well? Or are you going with some type of fabric wall

author: cian riordan
content: When I built my studio, the Unf*ck guys really wanted a bare, hard front wall. I was skeptical so I framed the front and gave my self the option to make it soft if needed. I ended up putting a 2 ft wide strip across the front of roxul behind the speakers. I put up some plywood to A/B it when I was finalizing the room and found the imaging to be tighter with a little bit of soft stuff behind the speakers. Now granted, the soft stuff is flush with the wall so the speakers are still as far back as you can go. But just food for thought. I was in another room recently that had great treatment, similar speakers, but a fully bare front wall and I definitely heard a less defined stereo image. Just my experience and preference.

author: peterlabberton
content: K, still procrastinating, and this one could get pricey, but: I'm going to try to soundproof as much as possible between the studio and the rest of the house. I keep odd hours, and when my girlfriend gets home at the time of day when normal people get home, I'm sometimes (read: often) right in the middle of the most productive part of my day. If I hear her making dinner or whatever, I'm almost certainly gonna use that as an excuse for a break, and ALSO I will be self-conscious that she's out there hearing me looping a weird part of the song I'm working on—and it all just takes me out of the moment. So I'm planning on getting double solid wood doors to the studio, and doing whatever I can in the construction phase to soundproof at a decent level (sadly without going SUPER deep on this, as that's out of the budget!).

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: More treatment needed in some spots and getting the best results requires non rectangular geometry. Isolation wasn’t too big of a priority and is great (can’t hear most cars driving by at all if you’re sitting in silence with your eyes closed) but was also very compromised by the outer “shell” being the exterior/weather shell. Speaker decoupling also didn’t go well and lots to still work out there

author: cian riordan
content: When you're done hemhoragging money on your install, I'd suggest sound anchors to hold the speakers. They will give you more flexibility over cinder blocks, allow you to lever the speakers over the console if you like, and will decouple them from the desk so you're not feeling the low end through your fingers/hands.
